Award.AwardTitle: PolarTREC - Teachers and Researchers Exploring and Collaborating
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Artic Research Consortium of the U.S. (ARCUS) will administer and implement, "Teachers and Researchers Exploring and Collaborating (PolarTREC)", an international program that brings together U.S. teachers to participate in cutting-edge field research with polar scientists in various, and often remote, locations in the Arctic and Antarctica. Through hands-on field experiences in the Arctic and Antarctica, participating teachers (pre-service and in-service) will improve teaching strategies, develop resources for their careers, and change how they teach STEM in the classroom. The program goal is to invigorate polar science education and understanding by bringing educators and polar researchers together in professional collaboration. By integrating research and education, PolarTREC will help sustain and grow the considerable scientific and public enthusiasm for polar research and education.

ARCUS will support a total of twelve teachers for Arctic field seasons in 2017 and Antarctic field seasons in 2017/2018. ARCUS will recruit, select, and match teachers and researchers, maintain a website for dissemination of information about the expeditions, provide orientation training for the teachers that includes field safety and communication training, provide travel support for the teachers to meet with scientists prior to deployments and for them to join the scientific expeditions in the field, and evaluate results of the program. Dissemination efforts via the website and public presentations are expected to reach many additional teachers, students, scientists and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
U.S. students' academic achievement in science continues to lag behind that of their peers in other countries. Research indicates that one way to improve student outcomes is to put highly trained and confident science teachers in classrooms. To that end, Arctic Research Consortium of the United States (ARCUS) has developed a teacher professional development program that provides teachers with an authentic research experience. PolarTREC-Teachers and Researchers Exploring and Collaborating, is a professional development opportunity that pairs U.S. middle and high school teachers with scientists that conduct research in the Arctic and Antarctic, to provide an authentic hands-on research experience. The program goal is to invigorate polar science education and understanding by bringing educators and researchers that work in the polar regions, together in professional collaboration. PolarTREC seeks to sustain and grow the considerable scientific and public enthusiasm for polar research and education.

In 2017-2018, ARCUS recruited, selected, and matched 11 classroom teachers with research teams conducting research in the Arctic and Antarctica. Of the 11 teams, 8 were in the Arctic and 3 were in Antarctica. The selected teachers were from around the U.S. and taught at a variety of school settings, including urban, rural, public and private schools. The research they participated in was very also varied and ranged from studying jellyfish in the Bering Sea, Alaska to gathering data from the Automated Weather Stations in Antarctica.

Communicating science and making it accessible to "all" can be challenging in remote settings. To help share the experience, the PolarTREC website (www.polartrec.com) is designed to share information as well as assist the teachers in their professional development and outreach activities. Each research expedition has its own page that includes journals written by the teachers for their audiences, photos, comments, and links to resources created by the teacher (e.g. lesson plans, webinars). Additionally, there is a back side to the website for the program participants which includes training modules, additional resources, and planning tools related to their professional development. All the program participants were trained at an in-person orientation held in Fairbanks, Alaska. The training included program expectations, education and outreach planning, field safety, and communication training. Travel support was provided to the teachers that shared their experiences at science and education conferences after their expedition.

Despite the challenges of remote communications, these teachers were successful in their outreach activities (see infographic):

  • 300+ journals were written, including two educators writing in English and Spanish
  • 2800+ photos taken and became part of the Polar Media Archive
  • 4,000 students connected with researchers in the Arctic and Antarctica through real-time PolarConnect events to classrooms in the United States and 20 other countries
  • 18 news stories including online news stories, magazine articles, TV and radio interviews
  • 18 lessons created by the educators and vetted by researchers that focus on research being conducted in the polar regions
  • 10 presentations, focusing on the polar field research experience and presented at conferences

In addition to the outreach highlights, data collected and analyzed through an evaluator provide evidence that the PolarTREC program is meeting its goals with:

  • Participating teachers reporting an increased ability and confidence to include the following science processes in their classroom lessons.
    • Analyzing and interpreting data
    • Using mathematics and computational thinking
    • Engaging in argument from evidence
    • Developing and using models
    • Obtaining, evaluating, and communicating information
    • Asking questions and defining problems
    • Students of PolarTREC teachers reported a statistically significant improvement in content knowledge about general science practices and about Polar science topics like tundra systems, ocean systems, and ice and snow knowledge.
    • Researchers reported that the PolarTREC program was beneficial to the scientific process of their projects.
    • PolarTREC teachers report impacts on their teaching and professional networks years after their expedition was complete (see quote below).

"It's hard to believe it's been three years since my PolarTREC expedition to Summit Station, Greenland. When I look back, I no longer recognize the teacher I was before PolarTREC. The experience changed my entire perspective. I always felt comfortable with the material I taught, but I didn't feel very comfortable for how "science" was done in the field. Now, I have so much more self-confidence because of having the firsthand experience working with my team. I feel as though the students I teach now benefit as well. Hardly a week goes by in class where I don't reference some aspect of the expedition. The students are always curious and want to know more. Also, students often shy away from STEM careers because they feel it pigeon holes them into doing one thing for the rest of their lives. I talk about all of the amazing people I met at Summit Station and how they have done so many different things related to STEM in some way."  - Steve Kirsche
